sourceDesc:
<<<<<<< HEAD
The Racovian catechisme vvherein you have the substance of the confession of those churches, which in the kingdom of Poland, and great dukedome of Lithuania, and other provinces appertaining to that kingdom, do affirm, that no other save the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, is that one God of Israel, and that the man Jesus of Nazareth, who was born of the Virgin, and no other besides, or before him, is the onely begotten Sonne of God. Racovian catechism. English. 1652. Smalcius, Valentin, 1572-1622. Socinus, Faustus, 1539-1604.
[8], 78, 81-128, 133-176 p.
for Brooer Janz, Printed at Amsterledam [sic] : 1652.
A translation of the Racovian catechism. The catechism was begun by Faustus Socinus, who died before the work was completed. It was reworked and completed by Valentin Smalcius, Hieronim Moskorzewski, and Johannes Völker. See E.M. Wilbur, "The history of Unitarianism", chap. 31. The first leaf is blank. Text is continuous despite pagination. Annotation on Thomason copy: "July 8". Reproduction of the original in the British Library.
=======
The Racovian catechisme vvherein you have the substance of the confession of those churches, which in the kingdom of Poland, and great dukedome of Lithuania, and other provinces appertaining to that kingdom, do affirm, that no other save the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, is that one God of Israel, and that the man Jesus of Nazareth, who was born of the Virgin, and no other besides, or before him, is the onely begotten Sonne of God. Racovian catechism. English. 1652. Smalcius, Valentin, 1572-1622. Socinus, Faustus, 1539-1604.
[8], 78, 81-128, 133-176 p.
for Brooer Janz, Printed at Amsterledam [sic] : 1652.
A translation of the Racovian catechism. The catechism was begun by Faustus Socinus, who died before the work was completed. It was reworked and completed by Valentin Smalcius, Hieronim Moskorzewski, and Johannes Völker. See E.M. Wilbur, "The history of Unitarianism", chap. 31. The first leaf is blank. Text is continuous despite pagination. Annotation on Thomason copy: "July 8". Reproduction of the original in the British Library.
Brooer Janz
